assessment.title: Online Lecture - Week 1 - UNIT I (1 of 2)

material.mattext:
Online Lecture Activity Instructions

  • This is a self-paced activity.

  • There is no time limit.

  • You may repeat the lecture and questions as many times as needed.

  • Take notes as you go to help with understanding.

  • Complete the comprehension questions as you go through the lecture.

Lesson for Unit I: Introduction to Data

Here is the content for this lesson:

Lecture 1.1:

  • Why do we need statistics?

OpenIntro Statistics Videos:

  • 1.1 - Using stents to prevent strokes
  • 1.2 - Data basics
  • 1.3A - Data collection principles
  • 1.3B - Sampling principles and strategies
  • 1.4 - Basic principles of experimental design

section.title: Lesson 1.1: Why do we need statistics?

material.mattext:
Why do we need statistics

Before reading through the slides, watch this video:

Lecture 1.1 - Questions

Based on the the slides discussion and the previous video, which of the following statements are true? (Select all that apply)
Statistics allows us to make inferences about populations from data
If we could eliminate all uncertainty then statistics wouldn't exist
If one switches to door 3, the probability of winning remains 1/3

section.title: OpenIntro Statistics 1.1 - Using stents to prevent strokes

material.mattext:
1.1 - Using stents to prevent strokes

Please closely watch the following video. You will be asked one related question to check your knowledge.

Questions: OpenIntro Video 1.1

Name Votes (in thousands) Campaign Spending (in thousands) Candidate's Age
John Silver 25 $310 62
Kate Woods 43 $700 50
Alex Garcia 10 $150 38

Consider the previous data table. Which of the following are "summary statistics" following the definition given in the previous video?

Important: Be sure to compute and double check all summary statistics presented in the options.

What do we mean by "random" fluctuation?

In the last video, it is mentioned at the end that differences between the treatment group and the control group could be due to random fluctuations. But according to statistics, what is randomness? In this video ("Is anything random?"), the concept of randomness is fully developed. Please watch until timestamp 4:10.

In the text box below, provide an example of a common situation from your daily life as a student that you would classify as a 'random' phenomenon following the definition discussed in the video.

1.2 - Data Basics

Please closely watch the following video. You will be asked two questions about it to test your knowledge.

Questions OpenIntro Video 1.2

1. Identify the type of variable in the following example:

"The number of YEAS votes received by a Bill passed in Congress."

Questions OpenIntro Video 1.2

2. Read the following hypothetical findings from a study and determine the type of relationship described:

"A study found that people with lower educational achievement are less likely to vote in presidential elections."

(Hint: What does the finding suggests for the likelihood of electoral participation for individuals who have a higher educational attainment?)
Positive relationship
Negative relationship
No relationship

1.3A - Data Collection Principles

Please closely watch this video. You will be asked one question about it to test your knowledge.

1. Consider the following hypothetical study's finding and identify the relationship between the variables:

"A survey shows that older individuals are less likely to support progressive policies compared to younger individuals."
Age is the explanatory variable, and support for progressive policies is the response variable.
Support for progressive policies is the explanatory variable, and age is the response variable.
Both variables are explanatory.
Both variables are response variables.

section.title: OpenIntro Statistics 1.3B - Sampling principles and strategies

material.mattext:
1.3B - Sampling principles and strategies

Please closely watch this video. You will be asked one question about it to test your knowledge.

Question

2. Select the sampling method that matches the following description: 

"Randomly selecting individuals from each age group to ensure all age groups are represented."
Simple Random Sampling.
Stratified Sampling.
Convenience Sampling.
Cluster Sampling.

section.title: OpenIntro Statistics 1.4 - Basic principles of experimental design

material.mattext:
1.4 - Basic principles of experimental design

Please closely watch this video. You will be asked one question about it to test your knowledge.

Questions OpenIntro Videos 1.4

In a study investigating the effect of watching a political debate on voter turnout, which of the following could be an appropriate placebo?
Watching a video about castles in 16th century England.
Watching a political advertisement for a minor party candidate.
Watching a documentary about the history of the Democratic Party.
Watching an analysis of recent election results.
